awd_titl_txt: Ice nucleation properties of well characterized single particle-droplet pairs assessed using a microfluidic platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Water droplets do not freeze spontaneously until -40 degrees C, unless there is a particle surface to act as a nucleus for the freezing process. Ice nucleation and the resulting freezing of water induced by particles and surfaces is important in many processes.  It plays a critical role in organ preservation and in the manufacturing and purification of pharmaceuticals, food, biomolecules, cosmetics, and nanomaterials.  Ice nucleation also plays a key role in cloud glaciation, the transformation of water droplets in a cloud to ice crystals.  Glaciated clouds are responsible for most precipitation over land.  Atmospheric ice nucleating particles that cause clouds to glaciate create significant changes in the structure and behavior of the clouds. This cloud freezing dramatically changes the lifetime of the cloud and increases its ability to precipitate. However, we lack a rigorous understanding of this heterogeneous ice nucleation process. We still do not understand what special properties make these rare one-in-a-million atmospheric particles effective at nucleating ice crystals. We also lack small transportable instruments that can determine the concentration and freezing temperature of atmospheric ice nucleating particles in real-time by sampling from suspended aerosol particles. This research addresses many of these short-comings through the development of a new microfluidic approach to continuously capture and measure ice nucleating particles. Individual particles are activated into liquid droplets, which are then captured into an oil flowing through a microchannel in a device fabricated from a soft polymer. By sending the microdroplets through a temperature gradient applied to the microfluidic device, the freezing temperature of each particle-droplet pair is determined optically as each droplet turns opaque upon freezing. The use of engineered carbon nanotubes and metal oxide nanoparticles as robust ice nucleating particle standards with well-defined and reproducible freezing temperatures will then be explored using our unique device. The importance of heterogeneous ice nucleation and phase transitions will be communicated to the public and to underrepresented K-12 students in particular by conducting hands-on educational activities at several local public schools through after-school programs. The students will conduct experiments where they induce freezing in a small cloud chamber. These activities will be developed into self-contained educational modules that will be shared with a larger number of educators.

A new approach will be developed for transferring individual size-selected aerosolized particles in microdroplets into a continuous oil flow in a microfluidic chip. This will enable new experimental avenues in numerous fields. The capture of particles - first activated into droplets using a cloud condensation nuclei counter - into the continuous oil flow will be optimized using scaling analysis to tune the aerosol and oil flow rates to ensure droplet impaction and coalescence that avoids bouncing or droplet shattering. A linear temperature gradient will be applied along the microchannel using micro-Peltier elements, and measured using an array of thin-film thermocouples. Temperature measurements along with numerical simulations will provide the temperature gradient field along the chip, allowing us to correlate the observed position of droplet freezing to its critical ice nucleation temperature. The lattice and surface properties of engineered nanoparticles will be determined and correlated to the ice nucleation ability we determine using the microfluidic device. This will be used to test our hypothesis that engineering nanoparticles will have tight and robust freezing temperature spectra. The uniform characteristics of these engineered nanoparticles should result in very reproducible freezing properties, creating improved ice nucleating particle standards that are greatly needed for ice nucleation measurements. This project brings together experts in aerosol science and technology, atmospheric chemistry, transport phenomena, and microfluidics, to perform truly interdisciplinary research. As this research focuses on advancing fundamental understanding of a key phase transition, it will have immediate impact on a wide range of fields in science and engineering, such as materials synthesis and purification, physical chemistry, the geophysical sciences, and anthropogenic climate change.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogeneous ice nucleation is the freezing of supercooled water that is catalyzed by a particle or other surface. This phase transition is a critical but still poorly understood phenomenon that has important effects on the formation, evolution and lifetime of clouds, the likelihood that they will produce precipitation, their radiative properties, and thus the effects of aerosol particles on weather and climate. Crystal nucleation is also important for materials synthesis and their properties in the food sciences, for cryopreservation, and for the production and purification of pharmaceuticals. What properties control the heterogeneous ice nucleation ability of a particle's surface remain under active investigation so that we can more accurately predict and control this phase transition.

Microfluidics where microdroplets are produced, manipulated, and analyzed on small lab-on-a-chip devices provide powerful yet easy to access ways for experimentally studying ice nucleation occurring in aqueous droplets. This research project sought to bridge the worlds of aerosol science and the atmospheric sciences with that of fluid mechanics and microfluidics to apply droplet microfluidic approaches to investigate the particle properties that control their observed ice nucleation activity. This research was the result of a interdisciplinary collaboration between experts from the fields of chemistry, physics, and chemical and mechanical engineering.

A new Microfluidic Ice Nucleation Technique (MINT) was developed using a store-and-create approach that produces an array of ~600 similarly-sized 6 nL microdroplets (~150 microns in diameter), each isolated in its our microwell on the microfluidic chip. Each droplet floats in the surrounding oil, avoiding contact with any solid surface that could act as a weak ice nucleant and cause background freezing that interferes with the sample analysis. The MINT device was demonstrated to obtain accurate droplet freezing temperature spectra with high statistics and a low background freezing temperature of -33 C. This enabled determining the ice nucleation ability of complex biomass-burning aerosol emitted from wildfires, a major source of pollution emitted episodically to the atmosphere. Minerals produced by the biomass fuel combustion were determined to be the source of the ice nucleating particles. This discovery helped to explain the long-standing mystery regarding why some biomass fuels produce ice nucleating particles, while others do not, and what the source of these rare and important particles are. Furthermore, the MINT approach developed here allowed us to determine that simulated atmospheric photochemical aging can further enhance the ice nucleation ability of the smoke particles, by removing organic carbon coatings that conceal the mineral-based ice nucleants.

A novel approach to capturing aerosol particles into a droplet microfluidic device that preserves the unique identity of each individual particle was also developed. Each particle is first activated into a water droplet through the condensation of water vapor. A custom nozzle was designed to transport the droplet to the oil-filled open channel of a microfluidic chip. A small vacuum flow applied to the nozzle bled some of the air from the aerosol droplet stream to reduce the total flow velocity arriving at the oil surface. Dimensionless analysis involving the Stokes number that predicts if the droplet will be intercepted by the oil, and the Weber number that predicts how the droplet will behave when it strikes the oil surface, was developed to tune the parameters of the droplet collection. The main identified parameters that govern if the droplet intercepts the oil surface and becomes engulfed in the oil are the droplet diameter (accounting for evaporation during transport) and the droplet velocity. These two parameters can be adjusted by changing the conditions of the condensational growth column and of the nozzle.

Optical microscopy was used to evaluate the success of the aerosol particle-droplet pair capture into the microfluidic device. The size distribution of the collected droplets was compared to that measured as the droplets leave the growth column before entering the nozzle, and evaluated with a model that accounts for droplet evaporation and particle-size dependent collection efficiency. Good droplet collection efficiency > 40% in the expected size range was observed, and droplet coalescence once transferred to the continuous oil phase of the microfluidic device was avoided by addition of an appropriate surfactant to the oil. The successful development of a new approach for transferring individual aerosol particles each suspended in a droplet into a microfluidic device opens numerous potential new avenues of scientific discovery. This enables the application of the many powerful droplet manipulation and analysis capabilities uniquely provided by microfluidic lab-on-a-chip devices to the study of aerosol particles in many fields of science and engineering.
